newsitem.title: UK: Studies narrow down how long drugs needed for HIV.
newsitem.headline: Studies narrow down how long drugs needed for HIV.

text.p: People infected with the HIV virus that causes AIDS received good news and bad news on Thursday -- drugs can probably kill off the virus but it will take years.

A flurry of studies showed that the cocktail approach using a combination of strong drugs can probably eventually get to every infected cell in the body, but it will take three years or more of the expensive and unpleasant treatment.

"It would be wrong to believe that we are close to a cure for AIDS," Dr David Ho of the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center at Rockefeller University in New York and colleagues wrote in a report in the science journal Nature.
"Given the high cost and toxicity of prolonged combination therapy, new strategies must be developed to facilitate the extinction of those viral 'embers' that could rekindle the infection."
Ho's team used a mathematical model to predict it would take 2.3 to 3.1 years, possibly more, to eliminate HIV from the immune system cells it attacks.
But scientists said the only way to truly know would be to watch people actually infected with HIV and see what happened.
"A blunt personal view is never to think you've outsmarted HIV," Simon Wain-Hobson of the Institut Pasteur in Paris wrote in a commentary in Nature.
Robert Siliciano of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore and colleagues looked at the cells that HIV lives in -- the CD4 immune system cells -- in 14 HIV-infected volunteers.
They found HIV persisted in about 0.05 percent of all the resting, or temporarily inactive, CD4 cells.

"These are the cells that are the long-term reservoir of the virus. They are not affected by drugs -- drugs only affect the virus during the replicative cycle," Siliciano said in a telephone interview.
"The good news is there aren't very many of these cells. The bad news is they can persist for a very long period of time."
Siliciano's work indicates that HIV needs only to hide in a very few CD4 cells -- maybe just one.
"The presumption is that a single infected cell, once activated, can produce enough virus cells to start the whole thing going again," he said.
Researchers at the University of Minnesota reported in the journal Science that they had found the combination therapy got to infected cells in the lymph nodes --one of the suspected "reservoirs".
"It's good news," said Dr Winston Cavert, one of the authors.
Scientists knew the drugs reduced the virus in blood by 99 percent, but were not sure HIV was not lurking somewhere else in the body, like the lymph nodes.

Two studies in the New England Journal of Medicine looked at newborns. One concluded that a combination of three drugs could reduce the amount of HIV in their blood without causing serious side-effects.
A second found that babies with the highest levels of HIV had a bigger risk of quickly developing one of the immunity-related diseases that are the hallmarks of AIDS.
Their findings raised the possibility that early treatment with new anti-HIV drugs may slow or prevent the development of AIDS in infants born to HIV-positive mothers.
